subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Bank of Queensland, CIMIC and Whitehaven Coal earnings updates
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP Capital (AMP AT)
- The banking royal commission reportedly took aim at key parts of Co.’s business model. (Newswires)
- AMP and Macquarie Super did not sign up to a new code of ethics aimed at reducing excessive life insurance fees related to super funds. (The Australian)
- Co. reportedly admitted it made false and misleading statements to the regulator regarding fee charges. (AFR)

Atlas Iron (AGO AT)
- Co. Q3 iron ore shipped 2.0mln WMT vs. Prev. 2.2mln WMT Q/Q. (Newswires)

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT)
- Co. H1 statutory NPAT AUD 174mln vs. Prev. AUD 171mln Y/Y. (Newswires)
- Co. H1 net interest income AUD 475mln vs. Prev. AUD 452mln.
- Co. H1 cash profit AUD 182mln vs. Exp. AUD 190mln.

CIMIC (CIM AT)
- Co. Q1 NPAT rose 7% to AUD 172mln, while revenue rose 7% to AUD 3.2bln. (Newswires)

Downer EDI (DOW AT)
- Co. receives contract valued at AUD 660mln over a 6½ year period. (Newswires)

Fletcher Building (FBU NZ)
- Wesfarmers confirmed it does not hold shares in the Co. (Newswires)
- Co. is to raise NZD 750mln through an entitlement offer and will offload businesses. (The Australian)

 Saracen Mineral Holdings (SAR AT)
- Co. Q3 output 98.9K ounces and raises FY18 gold output guidance to between 310k-315k ounces vs. Prev. guidance of around 300k ounces. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Co. hires Macquarie to assist with Coles spin-off. (AFR)

Whitehaven Coal (WHC AT)
- Co. quarterly coal sales rose to 5.4mln tons vs. Prev. 4.9mln tons, while coal output rose 3% from PCP to 5.3mln tons. (Newswires)
- Co. is to acquire stake in Winchester South Metallurgical coal project from Rio Tinto (RIO AT) in deal valued at AUD 200mln. (Newswires)

Winemakers
- Australia wines exports to China rose to over AUD 1bln for the first time. (AFR)

Basic Material / Energy
- Spot gold rose 0.3%.
- WTI crude fell 1.7%.
 

JAPAN

Astellas Pharma (4503 JT)
- Co. plans JPY 200bln spending on M&A. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (8306 JT)
- S&P affirmed Co. rating at A; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT)
- Co. Chairman Ghosn says mulling review of capital ties with Renault and that all options are open regarding capital structure. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. plans a multibillion-dollar bond issuance. (Newswires)

TEPCO (9501 JT) and other Nuclear power firms
- Niigata Governor who was seen to be an obstacle to the restart of reactors in the prefecture, is said to consider resigning. (Newswires)

Other news
- BoJ Deputy Governor Wakatabe said they are doing what needs to be done to reach price target and that the benefits outweigh the costs. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

CJ Logistics (000120 KS)
- Co. agreed with VietJet Air on a partnership deal as it aims to widen its presence overseas. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. shareholder Elliot is said to ask the board to increase dividends. (Newswires)

Korean Air Lines (003490 KS)
- Co. temporarily suspended Senior VP Cho who is the daughter of the Chairman for alleged misbehaviour towards an ad agency employee. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy says committee on protection of industrial technologies failed to reach an agreement whether to provide protection to chipmaking technologies as national core assets, amid ongoing dispute over workplace safety at Samsung Electronics. (Newswires)
- US judge ruled in patent dispute that Huawei cannot prevent Samsung from manufacturing in China. (Newswires)

UBS Weekly FX Flows: NZD inflows extended to the 5th week
content:
JPY, AUD most sold NZD was the most bought G10 currency and recorded its fifth consecutive week of inflows despite relatively light data flow as commodity prices enjoyed a rebound. 

GBP was heavily bought for a second week despite weaker than expected activity data. USD saw another week of marginal inflows with the most substantial buying interest registered on Thursday. 

JPY was the most sold G10 FX last week, experiencing its second straight week of outflows amid improving risk sentiment as AUD also saw net outflows for the second week in a row. 

NOK was sold despite the rally in oil as CPI printed softer than expected. 

EUR saw outflows for a second straight week as SEK was sold for a third, with the majority of outflows coinciding with a weaker than expected inflation print on Thursday. 

In EM, BRL registered inflows for the first time in 9 weeks.

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US is said to be considering ways to retaliate against Chinese restrictions on US tech firms. (WSJ)

New Zealand REINZ House Sales (Mar) Y/Y -9.9% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)
New Zealand REINZ March seasonally adjusted median house prices fell 2.2% M/M but rose 1.9% Y/Y.


UK/EU

ECB’s Praet said ample degree of monetary policy remains necessary and that policy must be patient, persistent and prudent, while he also commented that the growth outlook confirms ECB's confidence. (Newswires)


FX

The broad USD has gradually lost ground vs all G10 rivals over the course of Monday’s session, and the index has slipped back below 89.500 as a result. Tech support around 89.250 is therefore back in focus as more of the same between the US and China, could prompt another serious test of the nearest downside chart level. GBP and the EUR have been in a tug-of-war, but the latter is emerging as the winner with Cable looking set to test the 2018 high so far at 1.4345 (vs circa 1.4335 at best) and EURGBP under 0.8650, as pulls up just short of 1.2400 again despite surpassing a key Fib (1.2377) and effectively matching last week’s peak (1.2395 on Wednesday and prior to dovish/cautious ECB minutes from the March meeting). The CHF has been another decent gainer vs the Usd as the headline pair retreats below 0.9600 and the Franc largely shrugs off mixed producer/import inflation data. CAD/AUD/NZD: Not much to choose between the commodity bloc in terms of rankings within the majors on the day, as the Loonie recaptures sub-1.2600 territory ahead of Wednesday’s BoC meeting and Canadian CPI data on Friday, while AUDUS is poised to retest resistance ahead of 0.7800, like the 50 DMA around 0.7781. NZDUSD has regained 0.7350+ status ahead of Tuesday’s GDT auction and NZ Q1 CPI the day after, but is marginally lagging behind its antipodean neighbour as AUDNZD crosses back over 1.0550. JPY very rangebound vs the Greenback in the 107.20 area, with wider geopolitical factors basically offsetting more domestic political concerns, but the Jpy retaining an underlying safe-haven bid as US President Trump tweeted another warning to Russia and China about Rub and CNY devaluation.


COMMODITIES

Alberta introduced legislation which would restrict provincial exports of energy products including crude oil, nat gas and refined fuels. There were also comments from Alberta Premier Notley that the measures are tied to opposition to expansion of Kinder Morgan Pipeline and could impact British Colombia gasoline prices, while she added that the rules will permit Alberta to prioritize pipeline shipments of crude oil over refined fuel shipments. (Twitter)

Citigroup raised forecasts for average Brent crude prices by between USD 5.00-6.00 per barrel to USD 65.00/bbl for 2018 and to USD 55.00/bbl for 2019. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump is said to halt plan for further Russian sanctions. (Washington Post)


US

Fed's Dudley (Voter, Neutral) said that the Fed will remove accommodative policy in a year or two, while he added that he expects 3 or 4 gradual hikes this year and that any more is unlikely. Furthermore, he also noted 3% seems a reasonable estimate for the neutral rate. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bostic (Voter, Dove) said he has not seen much movement in wages. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said he sees cyclical wage pressure building this year but added that he does not see inflation moving higher even though confident wage pressure will build up. Furthermore, Kaplan also stated he is very concerned that fiscal stimulus will turn into headwinds in 3-5 years. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said recent steps by the federal government to stimulate economic growth have made him more confident the Fed will hit its 2% inflation objective soon, allowing the Fed to press ahead with planned interest-rate increases. (WSJ)

US President Trump is to nominate PIMCO’s economist Richard Clarida as Fed Vice Chair. (Newswires)

China's Treasury holdings of US Treasury rose from USD 8.5bln to USD 1.18trln in Feb. (Newswires)

US Retail Sales MM (Mar) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

UBS cut US Q1 GDP tracker to 1.7% (Prev. 1.8%) and Goldman Sachs cut US Q1 GDP tracker to 1.90% (Prev. 2.0%) after retail sales data. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Equity futures gapped higher at the open and traded sideways for most of the session. Action tended to focus around the 2680 region in ES, with the index struggling to hold onto gains above that level for the most part, trading between that level and the VWAP 2670 – 2675. Strong earnings boosted JB Hunt, which led the NASDAQ, and Bank of America (BAC), Charles Schwab (SCHW) and M&T (MTB) were all gainers after beating earnings’ expectations. In the M&A space, Marriott Vacations Worldwide (VAC) and ILG (ILG) were up more than 5%, after they announced to be in pole position to merge. Elsewhere, pharma names surged on news that Amazon (AMZN) has shelved its plan to sell and distribute pharmaceutical products after considering it last year, according to people familiar with the matter, (CAH, AET, RAD & WBA shares spiked higher following this). Attention also fell on Merck’s (MRK) Keytruda which showed signs of recurrence-free survival benefit across high risk stage 3 Melanoma, which also hampered Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) and Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) which closed among the lowest in the SPX. On the flip side, General Electric (GE) was dragged into negative territory after it announced a USD 4.24bln equity charge and reported reduced earnings for the last two years by USD 0.30/shr, In line with earlier announced expectations as it adjusted the figures to new accounting standards. SPX +0.8% at 2678, NDX +0.7% at 6675, DJI +0.9% at 24573.

Treasuries were sold as European traders got to their desks on Monday morning, as some of the geopolitical risk eased. However, Treasuries did find buyers over the course of the session, particularly after a mixed retail sales report, as well as the latest business inventories and NAHB data, but the buying wasn’t enough to prevent the complex from settling slightly lower. The shape of the curve saw some modest flattening on Monday. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick lower at 120-15.

US MARKET WRAP 16 April 2018: Geopolitical tensions ease
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks up, Treasuries flat, DXY down, crude down
* REAR-VIEW: Fed’s Bostic does not see much move in wage pressure, mixed US data, Fed’s and ECB’s speak
* AHEAD: RBA Minutes, China GDP, heavy Fed’s speak calendar

* GEOPOLITICS: Geopolitical risk abated on Monday, with Western forces intimating that the strike on Syria was a one-off as a result of chemical weapons use. Sentiment was helped late in the session after it was reported that US President Trump had halted a plan to impose further sanctions on Russia. Earlier on Monday, the EU also called on Iran and Russia to aid in preventing further use of chemical weapons. In the UK, PM May’s speech to Parliament Monday was mainly uneventful. A US envoy also noted there were concerns that Russia “may have tampered” with Douma attack site in Syria and called for OPCW members to condemn Syria for their "reign of chemical terror". Separately, Russia's deputy foreign minister said Moscow along with its G20 and BRIC partners are discussing the US's abuses of the USD as a main reserve currency.

* TRADE WARS: Markets remain on alert, awaiting for the US to announce the USD 100bln of Chinese products subject to additional tariffs. The European Union announced it was seeking talks with the US at the WTO, over compensation for US steel and aluminium tariffs, according to a filing, whilst news flow remained silent on the NAFTA front.

* FEDSPEAK: US President Trump said to nominate PIMCO’s economist Richard Clarida as Fed Vice Chair; when he spoke in January, Clarida endorsed three 2018 hikes. Fed’s Dudley (Voter, Neutral) claimed the Fed will remove accommodative policy in a year or two and that uncertainties and risks around trade remain as trade barriers would be bad for the economy. Fed’s Bostic (voter) reveleaed little by way of new information, though said he saw little movement in wages. Fed's Kashkari (dove, non-voter) is slowly adjusting his tone, noting on Monday once again that recent steps by the government to stimulate economic growth have made him more confident the Fed will hit its 2% inflation objective soon, allowing the Fed to press ahead with planned interest-rate increases. Fed’s Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) appeared confident the cyclical wage pressure will build up this year, he is concerned the fiscal stimulus will turn into headwind in 3-5 years and thus he still sees 3 rate hikes this year. He also mentioned that the 10yr yield at 2.85% places a limit on how high the Fed can lift rates.

*ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Praet (dove, chief economist) believes ample degree of monetary policy remains necessary, he added policy must be patient, persistent and prudent and the growth outlook confirms ECB's confidence.

* DATA: US DATA: US retail sales rebounded in March, ending a run of three consecutive monthly declines. Gains were driven by driven by autos. The control group - which is used in GDP calculations – also put in a firm showing. “Although we still expect a relatively weak consumer during the first quarter of the year, the better-than-expected retail sales report today plus the relatively strong control group sales number will keep first quarter consumption from being a complete disappointment after such a strong quarter at the end of last year,” Wells Fargo said. Business inventories were up 0.6% MM in February, and analysts noted that the stock piling was likely to add to GDP growth in Q1; Barclays subsequently raised its tracker by 0.1ppts to 1.6%, though the Atlanta Fed GDPnow tracker slipped by the same margin to 1.9% in Q1. The NAHB’s April survey fell by 1 point to 69 (analysts were expecting a 1 point rise to 71), marking the fourth consecutive month of declines. “The trend in mortgage applications now seems to be weakening - though the seasonals are so tricky at this time of year that we can't be sure - so we see further downside for the NAHB over the next few months. Housing has not led this economic cycle; it's not about to start now,” Pantheon Macroeconomics said.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.8% at 2678, NDX +0.7% at 6675, DJI +0.9% at 24573 // SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +0.75%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +1.01%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.01%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.47%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.8%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.00%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.38%, TECH (XLK): +0.7%, TELECOMS (XTL): +1.49%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.38%. Equity futures gapped higher at the open and traded sideways for most of the session. Action tended to focus around the 2680 region in ES, with the index struggling to hold onto gains above that level for the most part, trading between that level and the VWAP 2670 – 2675. Strong earnings boosted JB Hunt, which led the NASDAQ, and Bank of America (BAC), Charles Schwab (SCHW) and M&T (MTB) were all gainers after beating earnings’ expectations. In the M&A space, Marriott Vacations Worldwide (VAC) and ILG (ILG) were up more than 5%, after they announced to be in pole position to merge. Elsewhere, pharma names surged on news that Amazon (AMZN) has shelved its plan to sell and distribute pharmaceutical products after considering it last year, according to people familiar with the matter, (CAH, AET, RAD & WBA shares spiked higher following this). Attention also fell on Merck’s (MRK) Keytruda which showed signs of recurrence-free survival benefit across high risk stage 3 Melanoma, which also hampered Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) and Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) which closed among the lowest in the SPX. On the flip side, General Electric (GE) was dragged into negative territory after it announced a USD 4.24bln equity charge and reported reduced earnings for the last two years by USD 0.30/shr, In line with earlier announced expectations as it adjusted the figures to new accounting standards.

 * TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick lower at 120-15. Treasuries were sold as European traders got to their desks on Monday morning, as some of the geopolitical risk eased. However, Treasuries did find buyers over the course of the session, particularly after a mixed retail sales report, as well as the latest business inventories and NAHB data, but the buying wasn’t enough to prevent the complex from settling slightly lower. The shape of the curve saw some modest flattening on Monday.

* CRUDE: Some of the geopolitical risk premium baked into crude prices has unwound after Syria strikes are seen as a one-off in specific response to chemical weapons use. However, some geopolitical risk is still contained within the one-month view (US will decide in mid-May whether to re-apply sanctions on Iran, or back the nuclear deal) keeping some bid in crude. Crude action was generally horizontal following the selling overnight. In crude specific news, the Kuwaiti oil minister said OPEC-led  cuts will continue through the end of 2018, as planned, Oman’s oil minister urged producers to continue cooperation. State-side, the EIA said US total shale oil production for May is seen higher by 125,000BPD at 6.996mln BPD (April saw a 118,000 BPD rise). Analysts estimate that headline crude stocks will draw by 1.9mln barrels this week, Cushing stocks are seen drawing by 1.2mln in the week, according to Genscape; for products, the Street expects to see distillates draw by 0.5mln barrels and gasoline is seen drawing by 1mln in the week.

* FOREX:  The broad USD has gradually lost ground vs all G10 rivals over the course of Monday’s session, and the index has slipped back below 89.500 as a result. Tech support around 89.250 is therefore back in focus as more of the same between the US and China, could prompt another serious test of the nearest downside chart level. GBP and the EUR have been in a tug-of-war, but the latter is emerging as the winner with Cable looking set to test the 2018 high so far at 1.4345 (vs circa 1.4335 at best) and EURGBP under 0.8650, as pulls up just short of 1.2400 again despite surpassing a key Fib (1.2377) and effectively matching last week’s peak (1.2395 on Wednesday and prior to dovish/cautious ECB minutes from the March meeting). The CHF has been another decent gainer vs the Usd as the headline pair retreats below 0.9600 and the Franc largely shrugs off mixed producer/import inflation data. CAD/AUD/NZD: Not much to choose between the commodity bloc in terms of rankings within the majors on the day, as the Loonie recaptures sub-1.2600 territory ahead of Wednesday’s BoC meeting and Canadian CPI data on Friday, while AUDUS is poised to retest resistance ahead of 0.7800, like the 50 DMA around 0.7781. NZDUSD  has regained 0.7350+ status ahead of Tuesday’s GDT auction and NZ Q1 CPI the day after, but is marginally lagging behind its antipodean neighbour as AUDNZD crosses back over 1.0550. JPY very rangebound vs the Greenback in the 107.20 area, with wider geopolitical factors basically offsetting more domestic political concerns, but the Jpy retaining an underlying safe-haven bid as US President Trump tweeted another warning to Russia and China about Rub and CNY devaluation.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 flat) following suit from the Asia-Pac session as investors remain wary of potential escalating tensions regarding Syria
content:
16th April 2018

  • European bourses trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 flat) following suit from the Asia-Pac session as investors remain wary of potential escalating tensions regarding Syria.
  • The greenback is now softer for choice vs all G10 counterparts, albeit modestly
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US retail sales and Fed’s Bostic, Kaplan and Kashkari

 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded with a mixed tone as focus centred on air strikes on Syria over the weekend and Chinese data. The anticipated US-led response on Syria finally took place on Saturday, which was seen as somewhat of a slap on the wrist as they decided to hit only 3 targets and with the wave of strike action already declared to be over. As such, US equity futures gapped higher at the open, while ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were also in the green as fears of an escalation subsided. Conversely, Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) and Hang Seng (-1.6%) were negative following the miss on Chinese lending data last week and with tomorrow’s Chinese GDP adding to the risk factors, while the PBoC also announced to raise the 14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps which was in-line with the hikes seen in money market rates in reaction to the March Fed hike. This saw an increase in money market rates in Hong Kong, while underperformance was led by Rusal shares which tumbled over 20% after US announced to impose further Russian sanctions. Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful amid a subdued tone in USTs and indecisive risk sentiment in the region, while the absence of a BoJ Rinban announcement also ensured quiet trade. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful and traded little changed amid the mixed risk tone and as a lack of BoJ Rinban announcement also ensured quiet trade.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 70bln via 14-day reverse repos. PBoC hiked the14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps to 2.70% which was inline with the action taken on 7-day reverse repos after the Fed rate hike in March. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2884 (Prev. 6.2898)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Kashkari says recent steps by the federal government to stimulate economic growth have made him more confident the Fed will hit its 2% inflation objective soon, allowing the Fed to press ahead with planned interest-rate increases. (WSJ)

BoJ’s Deputy Governor Wakatabe says that it’s true a low interest rate environment is weighing on regional banks income. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US, UK and France conducted airstrikes in which over 100 missiles were launched at 3 Syrian targets in response to the chemical weapons use. US President Trump stated US is prepared to sustain response until Syria stops use of chemical weapons but added that US does not seek an indefinite presence in Syria, while Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Dunford said that this wave of airstrikes was finished. (Newswires)

EU is considering extending sanctions against Iran. (Spiegel)

Russian foreign ministry to study draft UN Syria resolution proposed by the US, UK and France. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly agreed to give parliament a full debate on the Syria airstrikes and has called for emergency debate this Monday afternoon regarding Syria. (Guardian/Sky)

Russian President Putin said that further strikes by the West on Syria would bring chaos to global affairs. (Newswires)

Russia's deputy foreign minister says Moscow along with its G20 and BRIC partners are discussing the US's abuses of the USD as a main reserve currency. (Newswires)

US envoy says there is concerns that Russia “may have tampered” with Douma attack site in Syria. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is to make a Brexit appeal in which she will urge the Commonwealth to bolster trade and forge new relationships. (Times)

The Institute for Government think tanks suggests that UK lawmakers could force PM May back into negotiations, a general election or a second referendum when it casts its decision on the ‘take-it-or-leave-it’ vote. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he is optimistic US and China can avoid a broader trade spat, while he also confirmed US President Trump wants to look into entering the TPP-11 but that it was too soon to determine how long the process would take. (Newswires) This also comes in the context of a WSJ piece stating that the earliest the U.S. could formally start negotiations to join the TPP is sometime next year, and each of the 11 nations still in the deal have a veto. (WSJ)

US Special Counsel Mueller is said to have evidence Trump's lawyer Cohen was in Prague during 2016 Presidential election, which reports state could lend credence to allegations by a former British spy that Cohen met a powerful Kremlin official. Elsewhere, it was also reported that US President Trump is said to have deep concerns on the direction Special Counsel Mueller is taking. (Newswires)

Former FBI Director Comey described the Oval office meeting in which he said President Trump asked him to back off of Michael Flynn which he thinks is certainly some evidence of obstruction of justice. However, he added that he doesn’t think President Trump should be impeached, but instead thinks Trump should be voted out. (Newswires)

Moody’s raised Spain’s sovereign rating by one notch to Baa1; outlook stable. Fitch affirmed Luxembourg at ‘AAA’; outlook stable. S&P affirmed Poland at BBB+; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses opened mixed (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%) this morning, following suit from the Asia-Pac session as investors remain wary of potential escalating tensions regarding Syria. The anticipated US-led response on Syria finally took place on Saturday, which was seen as somewhat of a slap on the wrist as they decided to hit only 3 targets and with the wave of strike action already declared to be over. In terms of sectors, energy is taking a hit from the falling oil prices whilst healthcare names are outperforming with Shire (+0.9%) higher on the day amid reports Takeda Pharmaceutical heads are to meet with US investors ahead of the GBP 35bln bid for the UK-listed pharma name. Furthermore, Shire is to sell their oncology business to unlisted French drugmaker Servier for USD 2.4bln. Whitbread (+6.7%) is dominating the FTSE 100 after reports Elliott Advisors is pressuring the company to spin-off Costa in an effort to generate as much as GBP 3bln of additional value. Elsewhere, WPP (-4.4%) following the departure of CEO Martin Sorrell after an allegation of personal misconduct, with concerns arising over the future course of action for the company.

FX

DXY

The Dollar index has faded after brief attempt higher within a 89.850-600 range, and the Greenback is now softer for choice vs all G10 counterparts, albeit modestly. Moreover, the ‘reaction’ to Saturday’s US-led strikes against Syria has been relatively tame overall, with the targeted military action appeasing fears over more aggression and potential retaliation.

EUR/GBP

Outperformers, as Eur/Usd firms above the 1.2300 handle, 10 DMA at 1.2310 and 55 DMA at 1.2327, but falls just short of a key Fib at 1.2377 having failed to seriously test 1.2400 on several occasions of late. Cable remains underpinned and just posted a session high above 1.4300 (best since the YTD high of 1.4345), and perhaps buoyed by a Eur/Gbp sell recommendation from a big US bank eying 0.8475 vs a circa 0.8645 low/0.8670 high.

JPY/CHF/NZD/CAD/AUD

All essentially flat vs the Usd, around 107.20, 0.9600, 0.7355 and 1.2600 respectively and awaiting further impetus. Dovish BoJ commentary has weighed on the Jpy, and similarly soft Swiss producer prices for the Franc, while the Loonie is looking for independent direction from the BoC on Wednesday and Canadian CPI on Friday. Aud/Usd is holding towards the upper end of a 0.7785-50 band, but also capped ahead of the nearest big figure after topping out just above last week.

USD/RUB

The Rouble is under pressure again amidst 62.0000-63.1500 parameters vs the Dollar ahead of latest reciprocal sanctions from the US and Russia, as the latter pledges to respond forcefully, and also warning that further strikes vs Syria will not be tolerated.

FIXED INCOME

A bit of respite for Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries, but it’s an uneasy calm as relief over the strategic nature of strikes against Syria is tinged with a degree of anticipation given still very strained relations between the West and Russian/Iran – more sanctions in the pipeline. The 10 year benchmark debt futures and corresponding cash yields are just off lows and highs respectively, but the technical picture has turned negative and downside objectives are very much on the radar, and within striking distance. As noted previously, 158.59-55 is next in sight for Bund bears, while Gilt sellers have 121.44 to aim for and USTs 120-03 now that Friday’s session base has been eclipsed. For reference, 158.88, 121.71 and 120-10 are the current levels.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures trade lower amid an unwind of the geopolitical premium and another uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count on Friday. The unwind in risk comes following the Syrian strikes on Saturday which were not as wide-reaching as some had feared. This risk-on attitude is tempered, however, as markets await further action surrounding Russian sanctions and retaliatory effects. In terms of energy specific newsflow, OPEC members continue to advocate further cooperation and reiterate that the current supply cuts are to continue to the end of the year. In the metals scope, news arising gold trades slightly softer on an improved risk appetite, and copper is uneventful following Chinese underperformance.

Kuwait Oil Minister says June meeting will be a chance to review agreement, but the deal will continue until the end of 2018. (Newswires)

Cable remains underpinned between 1.4225-70, and perhaps buoyed by a Eur/Gbp sell recommendation from a big US bank eying 0.8475 vs a circa 0.8645 low/0.8670 high.

JPY/CHF/NZD/CAD

All essentially flat vs the Usd, around 107.20, 0.9600, 0.7355 and 1.2600 respectively and awaiting further impetus. Dovish BoJ commentary has weighed on the Jpy, and similarly soft Swiss producer prices for the Franc, while the Loonie is looking for independent direction from the BoC on Wednesday and Canadian CPI on Friday.

USD/RUB

The Rouble is under pressure again amidst 62.0000-63.1500 parameters vs the Dollar ahead of latest reciprocal sanctions from the US and Russia, as the latter pledges to respond forcefully, and also warning that further strikes vs Syria will not be tolerated.

Fixed Income

Some corrective or catch-up selling straight off the Liffe re-start for Gilts, which have traded between 121.92-64 vs the 122.05 previous settlement price. The 10 year benchmark is tracking fixed counterparts lower in what looks like a technical downturn prompted by no major risk-aversion or fall-out from the strikes against Syria over the weekend. Note, Bunds have now not only breached 159.00, but also last week’s 158.89 low amidst stops to hit 158.74 for a decline of 60 ticks on the day, and bears/shorts will now be targeting the 158.59-55 area, while nearest chart support for Gilts comes in at 121.44 (late March low). The Short Sterling strip is 1-2 ticks below par and holding in relatively better amidst broad curve re-steepening and with some downbeat/dovish impulses via soft UK house price data and weak spending (Rightmove and VISA surveys respectively).

Commodities

WTI and Brent futures trade lower amid an unwind of the geopolitical premium and another uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count on Friday. The unwind in risk comes following the Syrian strikes on Saturday which were not as wide-reaching as some had feared. This risk-on attitude is tempered, however, as markets await further action surrounding Russian sanctions and retaliatory effects. In terms of energy specific newsflow, OPEC members continue to advocate further cooperation and reiterate that the current supply cuts are to continue to the end of the year. In the metals scope, news arising gold trades slightly softer on an improved risk appetite, and copper is uneventful following Chinese underperformance.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from WPP, Deutsche Bank and Sanofi.
content:
16th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded with a mixed tone as focus centred on air strikes on Syria over the weekend and Chinese data. The anticipated US-led response on Syria finally took place on Saturday, which was seen as somewhat of a slap on the wrist as they decided to hit only 3 targets and with the wave of strike action already declared to be over. As such, US equity futures gapped higher at the open, while ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were also in the green as fears of an escalation subsided. Conversely, Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) and Hang Seng (-1.6%) were negative following the miss on Chinese lending data last week and with tomorrow’s Chinese GDP adding to the risk factors, while the PBoC also announced to raise the 14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps which was in-line with the hikes seen in money market rates in reaction to the March Fed hike. This saw an increase in money market rates in Hong Kong, while underperformance was led by Rusal shares which tumbled over 20% after US announced to impose further Russian sanctions. Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful amid a subdued tone in USTs and indecisive risk sentiment in the region, while the absence of a BoJ Rinban announcement also ensured quiet trade.

FTSE

WPP (WPP LN) – CEO Martin Sorrell resigns after running the advertising agency for more than three decades following an allegation of personal misconduct. (FT)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – Co.’s largest shareholder, Elliott Advisors believes splitting Costa Coffee and Premier Inn would take the Co. less than five months and would cost less than GBP 20mln. Co. is under pressure as Elliott is pushing for a spin-off of Costa through a float in an effort to create as much as GBP 3bln of additional value. (The Times)

Shire (SHP LN) – Takeda (4502 JT) head is to meet with US investors ahead of a GBP 35bln bid for Shire. (Telegraph)

Smurfit Kappa (SKG LN) – Two of the Co.’s largest shareholders are calling on the Co. to enter into negotiations with International Paper (IP. (Newswires)

Motor insurance names - The cost of a comprehensive motor insurance policy was down 7% in the UK in Q1, the largest Q1 reduction seen in premiums in 4 years. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

ASOS (ASC LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

BHP BILLITON (BLT LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

BARCLAYS (BARC LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

TESCO (TSCO LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT SOCGEN

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DB GY) - ECB supervisors have asked the bank to calculate to the costs of winding down its investment banking division. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Italian minister says Lufthansa’s bid for Alitalia is the most promising, and adds that Alitalia are fragile. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Rocket Internet (RKET GY) – Co. are to terminate their share buyback programme early and will subsequently conclude today. (Newswires)

Software AG (SOW GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 187mln vs. Exp. EUR 220mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

COMMERZBANK (CBK GY)  INITIATED WITH AN UNDERPERFORM RATING AT CREDIT SUISSE

CAC

Sanofi (SAN FP) - A deal for Sanofi's generic unit is close to completion for Advent International. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

ADP (ADP FP) – Reports 8.3mln passengers went through Paris Airport in March 2018, +5.5% YY. (Newswires)

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. has received FDA clearance for Cobas. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Sulzer (SUN SW) – Co. has had all of its assets unblocked by the US treasury. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Caixabank (CABK SM) – Co. are contemplating purchasing a 15% stake in Cellnex Telecom from Atlantia, according to sources. (Newswires)

SCANDAVANIA

BROKER MOVES

CHR HASNSEN (CHR DC) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

US

EQUITIES: SPX -0.29% at 2656, NDX -0.42% at 6628, DJI -0.50% at 24360 

SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -0.57%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.50%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.10%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -1.55%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.08%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.24%, MATERIALS (XLB): -0.10%, TECH (XLK): -0.33%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.15%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.69%. 

Overnight equity futures took out yesterday’s highs rising to 2680 just before the cash open, when the gains were reversed and the EMINI faded back down. Further pressured by softer University of Michigan and JOLTS data was seen, with the EMINI returning to the 2650 area, a level that was revisited plenty of times this week.

Despite earnings for three major financial names today (JPM, Citi, Wells – all beating the top and bottom line), the sector closes red on Friday, with the financial sector underperforming. Energy was the outperformer, supporting the SPX for the session on the back of higher oil prices. Apart from the financial earnings, the main story stock specific stories today surrounded chip names, Qualcomm (QCOM) & Broadcom (AVGO), with the latter announcing a $12bln share repurchase programme after market on Thursday, and the former reportedly looking to become private in the next few months according to sources. M&A news was relatively light compared to recent sessions, where the focus was on Mylan (MYL) reportedly in advanced negotiations for German Merck’s KGaA (MRK GY) consumer health unit, sources suggest the bidding value is around $3.5bln.

Leading the S&P today was Alaska Air (ALK) following its March traffic report, and one of the laggards being PNC Financial (PNC) following earnings which EPS matched analyst expectations, but revenues missed.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded with a mixed tone as focus centred on air strikes on Syria over the weekend and Chinese data
content:
• Asian stocks traded with a mixed tone as focus centred on air strikes on Syria over the weekend and Chinese data
  • US, UK and France conducted airstrikes in which over 100 missiles were launched at 3 Syrian targets in response to the chemical weapons use
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US retail sales and Fed’s Bostic


ASIA

Asian stocks traded with a mixed tone as focus centred on air strikes on Syria over the weekend and Chinese data. The anticipated US-led response on Syria finally took place on Saturday, which was seen as somewhat of a slap on the wrist as they decided to hit only 3 targets and with the wave of strike action already declared to be over. As such, US equity futures gapped higher at the open, while ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were also in the green as fears of an escalation subsided. Conversely, Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) and Hang Seng (-1.6%) were negative following the miss on Chinese lending data last week and with tomorrow’s Chinese GDP adding to the risk factors, while the PBoC also announced to raise the 14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps which was in-line with the hikes seen in money market rates in reaction to the March Fed hike. This saw an increase in money market rates in Hong Kong, while underperformance was led by Rusal shares which tumbled over 20% after US announced to impose further Russian sanctions. Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful amid a subdued tone in USTs and indecisive risk sentiment in the region, while the absence of a BoJ Rinban announcement also ensured quiet trade. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful and traded little changed amid the mixed risk tone and as a lack of BoJ Rinban announcement also ensured quiet trade.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 70bln via 14-day reverse repos. PBoC hiked the14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps to 2.70% which was inline with the action taken on 7-day reverse repos after the Fed rate hike in March. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2884 (Prev. 6.2898)

UK

UK Rightmove House Prices (Apr) M/M 0.40% (Prev. 1.50%). (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Apr) Y/Y 1.60% (Prev. 2.10%)

UK Q1 Visa spending fell by the most since Q4 2012 as it dropped 1.4% vs. Prev. decline of 1.3%, while March Visa spending fell by most since October last year at -2.1% vs. Prev. -1.0%

UK PM May is to make a Brexit appeal in which she will urge the Commonwealth to bolster trade and forge new relationships. (Times)

The Institute for Government think tanks suggests that UK lawmakers could force PM May back into negotiations, a general election or a second referendum when it casts its decision on the ‘take-it-or-leave-it’ vote. (Newswires)


EU

German Interior Minister rejected demand by Verdi public sector union for a 6% wage hike. (Newswires)

Moody’s raised Spain’s sovereign rating by one notch to Baa1; outlook stable. Fitch affirmed Luxembourg at ‘AAA’; outlook stable. S&P affirmed Poland at BBB+; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)
 

FX

Major pairs were relatively quiet and began the week range-bound amid a lack of key data releases. Nonetheless, the greenback was slightly softer which marginally benefitted both EUR/USD and GBP/USD, while USD/JPY pulled-back as the overall risk tone gradually deteriorated. Elsewhere, HKD continued to test the 7.8500 bottom-end of the trading band and with it the resoluteness of the HKMA to intervene, while RUB underperformed and weakened over 1.5% against the greenback after the US stated that more Russian sanctions were to be announced today.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures pulled back below USD 67/bbl as geopolitical concerns abated following a somewhat restrained US-led strike on Syria, while the latest Baker Hughes data on Friday had also showed an increase in the number of oil rigs. Elsewhere, gold was indecisive alongside the overall risk tone and as a lacklustre greenback kept prices contained, while copper was also uneventful with mild losses amid the underperformance in its largest consumer China.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (13 Apr) 1008 (Prev. 1003). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US, UK and France conducted airstrikes in which over 100 missiles were launched at 3 Syrian targets in response to the chemical weapons use. US President Trump stated US is prepared to sustain response until Syria stops use of chemical weapons but added that US does not seek an indefinite presence in Syria, while Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Dunford said that this wave of airstrikes was finished. (Newswires)

White House said that US President Trump wants US forces to return home from Syria as soon as possible. (Newswires)

US Ambassador to the UN Haley said that there will be further sanctions on Russia which will be announced this Monday. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly agreed to give parliament a full debate on the Syria airstrikes and has called for emergency debate this Monday afternoon regarding Syria. (Guardian/Sky)

Russian President Putin said that further strikes by the West on Syria would bring chaos to global affairs. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasury yields were little changed on Friday with most action in the short end of the curve where 2yr yields rose to fresh (almost) decade highs. The rise in 2yr yields resulted in further flattening of the 2s10s and 2s30s curves (by around 3pbs). Treasuries were generally fulfilling their haven role, inversely moving to the direction of equities – particularly so after weak US data. Elsewhere, ahead of next week’s auction of 5yr TIPS, the US Treasury has asked primary dealers opinion on increasing 5yr TIPS issuance in the second half of the year. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick higher at 120-15+.

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he is optimistic on reaching a deal in principle on NAFTA, possibly in the third week of May. However, he also added that if no accord is reached by the Mexican election, a deal is unlikely to be reached until the end of the year. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he is optimistic US and China can avoid a broader trade spat, while he also confirmed US President Trump wants to look into entering the TPP-11 but that it was too soon to determine how long the process would take. (Newswires) This also comes in the context of a WSJ piece stating that the earliest the U.S. could formally start negotiations to join the TPP is sometime next year, and each of the 11 nations still in the deal have a veto. (WSJ)

US Special Counsel Mueller is said to have evidence Trump's lawyer Cohen was in Prague during 2016 Presidential election, which reports state could lend credence to allegations by a former British spy that Cohen met a powerful Kremlin official. Elsewhere, it was also reported that US President Trump is said to have deep concerns on the direction Special Counsel Mueller is taking. (Newswires)

Former FBI Director Comey described the Oval office meeting in which he said President Trump asked him to back off of Michael Flynn which he thinks is certainly some evidence of obstruction of justice. However, he added that he doesn’t think President Trump should be impeached, but instead thinks Trump should be voted out. (Newswires)
